docs.snippet: FILM It's a good week for glamorous Oscar-winners at the Regency, in ''The Leading Ladies'' series. This week, Elizabeth Taylor, Julie Christie, Katharine Hepburn and Audrey Hepburn are represented, while a French program spotlights Isabelle Adjan...
docs.lead_paragraph: FILM It's a good week for glamorous Oscar-winners at the Regency, in ''The Leading Ladies'' series. This week, Elizabeth Taylor, Julie Christie, Katharine Hepburn and Audrey Hepburn are represented, while a French program spotlights Isabelle Adjani in ''The Story of Adele H'' and Anna Karine in ''My Life to Live.''

docs.snippet: Historians of modern jazz have been curiously and almost unanimously parsimonious in their appraisals of Lennie Tristano, the pianist, composer, bandleader, theoretician, teacher, and recluse.  When Mr. Tristano died of a heart attack at his home ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Historians of modern jazz have been curiously and almost unanimously parsimonious in their appraisals of Lennie Tristano, the pianist, composer, bandleader, theoretician, teacher, and recluse. When Mr. Tristano died of a heart attack at his home in Queens on Nov. 18, 1978, only one album of his work was in print, and it was on a Japanese label. Most critical accounts of the development of modern jazz in the 1940's and 1950's treated him as an interesting but minor footnote, more impressive as the mentor of first-rate improvisers l ike Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh than as a musician in hisown right. The reasons for Mr. Tristano's exclusion fr om so many jazz critics' pantheons are almost as interesting as the pianist's longneglected music. He has been taken to tas k for emphasizing melodic counterpoint and difficult, altered h armonies while bullying his drummers into functioning as self-effacin g human metronomes. The Dutch critic Martin Schouten has called the s ound of the pianist's bands ''pale'' and ''characterless'' and conc luded that Mr. Tristano's recordings betrayed a ''lack of fe eling for the role of 'sound' in jazz.''

docs.snippet: ''SHOOT THE MOON,'' written by the Oscar-winning Bo Goldman (''Melvin and Howard'' and ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'') and directed by Alan Parker (''Fame'' and ''Midnight Express''), is a bittersweet comedy about a marriage that has gone sma...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''SHOOT THE MOON,'' written by the Oscar-winning Bo Goldman (''Melvin and Howard'' and ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'') and directed by Alan Parker (''Fame'' and ''Midnight Express''), is a bittersweet comedy about a marriage that has gone smash before the film opens. It is so funny, harrowing, intelligent and moving for so much of the time that when occasionally it goes wrong, one feels betrayed, far angrier than one would under other circumstances. One comes to identify with it so intimately that its lapses in judgment and imagination are all the more maddening, like watching a person you care about do something needlessly, suicidally stupid.

headline.main: FINNEY AND MISS KEATON IN 'SHOOT THE MOON'

docs.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Elizabeth J. Block, a financial writer, is working on a book about women and credit. By ELIZABETH J. BLOCK   THOSE of us who appreciate designer endorsements were heartened to l...
docs.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elizabeth J. Block, a financial writer, is working on a book about women and credit. By ELIZABETH J. BLOCK THOSE of us who appreciate designer endorsements were heartened to learn that Bill Blass is now designing chocolates for Godiva. At last, some relief from the crushing anonymity of most food. How reassuring to know that a real designer has, as it were, sweated over this chocolate, arranging its form and color, guaranteeing its originality before stamping his initials into every costly piece.

docs.snippet: Eva Hoffman is an editor on The Week in Review. A native of Poland, she has taught literature in several American universities. By Eva Hoffman   He is a tall, robust man of 70 years with a sturdy face, dramatic blue eyes framed by prominent cheekb...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eva Hoffman is an editor on The Week in Review. A native of Poland, she has taught literature in several American universities. By Eva Hoffman He is a tall, robust man of 70 years with a sturdy face, dramatic blue eyes framed by prominent cheekbones and bushy, white eyebrows. He stands in a sparsely furnished apartment overlooking a snowy street in Cambridge, Mass., and he thinks back just a few days to the telephone call that brought the news of the military crackdown in Poland. As he speaks about this latest tragedy in his country, the poet and Nobel Laureate Czeslaw Milosz maintains his customary control, but the intensity of his feelings comes through. The precise, accented voice is grave and the eyes are charged w ith anger. ''Solidarity,'' he says, ''was a great hope for the whole world. Within the Soviet system an alternative was being worked out that was outside both Communism and capitalism.'' Then his expression changes, and the sadness turns to bitterness. ''Poles are known,'' he says, ''for trying the impossible. In World War II they attacked tanks with lances. No expert would have believed that the Soviet system would tolerate Solidarity - and it didn't.''

headline.main: THE POET OF THE POLISH DIASPORA

docs.snippet: AS the impact of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts begins to take effect, Hofstra University, which was founded in 1935 during the first Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, will celebrate from March 4 to 7 the centennial of the birth of...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS the impact of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts begins to take effect, Hofstra University, which was founded in 1935 during the first Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, will celebrate from March 4 to 7 the centennial of the birth of the man who gave leadership to the United States during the Great Depression and who remains a symbol to many of a massive Federal aid program that gave help to those who could not help themselves. The celebration had its origins in a conversation last year between Dr. Herbert D. Rosenbaum of Rockville Centre, a professor of political science, and Harold A. Klein of Great Neck, director of university relations. Mr. Klein, whose interest in Roosevelt goes back to childhood, said: ''He was President from my 8th year to my 20th. I carried a banner at age 11 for him in a Bronx torchlight parade in the 1936 election.''
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  John Mortimer, who wrote the television adaptation of ''Brideshead Revisited,'' is a British playwright, author and barrister. His ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' series was shown on ...
docs.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Mortimer, who wrote the television adaptation of ''Brideshead Revisited,'' is a British playwright, author and barrister. His ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' series was shown on American public television last year. By JOHN MORTIMER LONDON Evelyn Waugh wrote ''Brideshead Revisited'' during a five-month leave from military service in 1944. It was a bleak period of our history, a time, as he said, ''of soya beans and Basic English,'' and so he produced a book that saw the past in a roseate glow. The splendors of country-house life took on a glamour, and Oxford in the 1920's appeared to have a succulent decadence, which may never have been apparent at the time. The book, as he said, tells us more about the England of the 1940's than it does of the 20's and 30's: Our dreams of the days that are gone throw less light on our past than on our present situation.

docs.snippet: Anyone who thinks that audiences are sheep -docile creatures to be pushed by critics and other self-appointed shepherds toward movies they otherwise would never see - should take a minute to look over the recent box office figures in Variety. To o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who thinks that audiences are sheep -docile creatures to be pushed by critics and other self-appointed shepherds toward movies they otherwise would never see - should take a minute to look over the recent box office figures in Variety. To optimists who have faith in the independence of the American consumer, these reports support their wildest dreams. To the rest of us, they are a little scary and, even after the fact, more than a little baffling. The season's biggest hits are not only the films that have been critically acclaimed or that have prompted serious controversy, like ''Reds'' or ''Pennies From Heaven,'' but also movies of such fecklessness that even their success can't teach us any special lessons. Take ''Modern Problems,'' the mildly amusing Chevy Chase film about a radioactive air traffic controller, a film with exactly four laughs in it, and ''Neighbors,'' John Avildsen's gross, clumsy adaptation of Thomas Berger's novel, starring John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. Both are among Variety's top-10 current moneymakers.

headline.main: Film View; FATHOMS DEEP IN THE MYSTERIES OF TASTE

docs.snippet: The splendid long limousines pulled up to the curb of the New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue Thursday night to disgorge their cargoes of splendidly dressed people -New York's most powerful fashion designers, retailers and perso...
docs.lead_paragraph: The splendid long limousines pulled up to the curb of the New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue Thursday night to disgorge their cargoes of splendidly dressed people -New York's most powerful fashion designers, retailers and personalities. But at the curb, elegantly clad guests such as Diana Vreeland, Mary McFadden, Grace Mirabella, the editor of Vogue, and the designer Jackie Rogers had to avoid slipping and falling in their satin gowns and chignons into the mounds of snow and slush.

headline.main: Notes on People; Of Satin and Slush

byline.original: By Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas Jr

docs.snippet: Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he considered the Baltimore Orioles an attractive team to play for next year because the Orioles would give him the opportunity to be an outfielder as well as a designated hitter and because they would be a conte...
docs.lead_paragraph: Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he considered the Baltimore Orioles an attractive team to play for next year because the Orioles would give him the opportunity to be an outfielder as well as a designated hitter and because they would be a contending team in the same division as the Yankees. Jackson's comments were made by telephone from his New York apartment on the morning after a meeting in Washington with Edward Bennett Williams, the Orioles' owner, and Hank Peters, the team's general manager. ''The Baltimore thing is intriguing,'' said Matt Merola, Jackson's business adviser, who attended Tuesday night's meeting. ''They're a solid team with a good chance of winning the pennant. They come to New York three times and they're an East Coast team so Reggie's name wouldn't get lost because there are no box scores in the paper from night games in California.''
